title: IPL madness: Cricket’s $27 million day
text:
Pat Cummins has a reserve price of $389,000. Source: AAP 
WHAT THE AUSTRALIANS ARE ALREADY MAKING 
Whatever happens on Monday, there already Australians who will make a killing in this year’s IPL. 
Over $10 million has been promised to Australian talent this season, with 17 players retained by their clubs from last season. 
Five Australians — Shane Watson, James Faulkner, Glenn Maxwell, Steve Smith, David Warner — have locked down contracts worth more than $1 million, with Watson leading the way with a $1.85 million deal with Royal Challengers Bangalore. 
Check out the IPL bid prices of all the retained Australian players: 
Millionaires’ Club ($6,620,000) 
Shane Watson — $1.85 million (Royal Challengers Bangalore) 
James Faulkner — $1.46 million (Gujarat Lions) 
Glenn Maxwell — $1.17 million (Kings XI Punjab) 
Steve Smith — $1.07 million (Rising Pune Supergiants) 
David Warner — $1.07 million (Sunrisers Hyderabad) 
Six-Figure Club ($3,281,000) 
Mitchell Starc — $973,000 (Royal Challengers Bangalore) 
Mitchell Marsh — $935,000 (Rising Pune Supergiants) 
Shaun Marsh — $428,000 (Kings XI Punjab) 
Chris Lynn — $253,000 (Kolkata Knight Riders) 
Usman Khawaja — $195,000 (Rising Pune Supergiants) 
Moises Henriques — $195,000 (Sunrisers Hyderabad) 
Aaron Finch — $195,000 (Gujarat Lions) 
Marcus Stoinis — $107,000 (Kings XI Punjab) 
Five-Figure Club ($349,000) 
Ben Cutting — $97,000 (Sunrisers Hyderabad) 
Andrew Tye — $97,000 (Gujarat Lions) 
Travis Head — $97,000 (Royal Challengers Bangalore) 
Adam Zampa — $58,000 (Rising Pune Supergiants) 
Total: $10,025,000 Shane Watson has a $1.85 million contract. Source: AFP 
THE BIGGEST EARNERS IN THE COMPETITION 
Remarkably, Watson’s salary is nowhere near being the biggest in the competition. 
Seven players have garnered contracts worth $2.43 million, with South Africa’s David Miller the only foreign player on the list. 
Unsurprisingly, both Virat Kohli and MS Dhoni are among the seven. 
Check out the IPL bid prices for the biggest earners in the competition: 
MS Dhoni (Rising Pune Supergiants) 
Suresh Raina (Gujarat Lions) 
David Miller (Kings XI Punjab) 
Gautam Gambhir (Kolkata Knight Riders) 
Rohit Sharma (Mumbai Indians) 
Virat Kohli (Royal Challengers Bangalore) 
Shikhar Dhawan (Sunrisers Hyderabad) Between the two of them, Virat Kohli and MS Dhoni will make $4.86 million this season. Source: Getty Images 
WHO HAS WHAT TO SPEND 
Kings XI Punjab have approximately $4.52 million available to them for the auction despite only releasing four players from the squad they had last year. 
Having released Johnson after a lacklustre season, Kings XI could go after a new star fast bowler. 
The Delhi Daredevils have the next most to spend — roughly $4.17 million — and could invest in overseas talent. The Daredevils need cover for the South African trio of JP Duminy, Quinton de Kock and Chris Morris, who are all likely to leave the competition early for national duty. 
Sunrisers Hyderabad are the only other side with more than $4 million ($4.04 million) to spend. Sunrisers have released six players from the squad that took them to the title last year. It wouldn’t be the worst idea for them to chase a batsman to compliment David Warner and Shikhar Dhawan. The openers were the only Hyderabad players to finish in the top 25 run-scorers last season. 
The Kolkata Knight Riders have $3.82 million to spend and are likely use much of it on overseas players, having released six foreign stars and lost Andre Russell to an anti-doping violation. Replacing Russell’s power-hitting and quality bowling will be top of the agenda. 
Having finished second-last in their debut season, Rising Pune Supergiants have $3.70 million to make things right this year. Pune badly need to beef up their arsenal of fast bowlers. 
The Gujarat Lions also debuted last year and finished the regular season atop the ladder. They have $2.78 million to spend and should use most of it on Indian talent as they already have six overseas players in their squad. 
Boasting the tournament’s most powerful batting order, — Virat Kohli, AB de Villiers, Chris Gayle, Watson — Royal Challengers Bangalore made it all the way to the final last year. Aside from Mitchell Starc, they are short any real star power in their bowling attack so they could spend a large chunk of their $2.48 million here. 
The Mumbai Indians have $2.24 million available to them. A quality quick to cover for the injury prone Lasith Malinga would make sense. Pat Cummins and Mitchell Johnson are both hoping to score big deals on Monday. Source: FOX SPORTS 
TOURNAMENT SCHEDULE 
The tournament kicks off on March 2, with MS Dhoni’s Supergiants taking on Kohli’s Bangalore. 
Each of the eight sides will play each other twice, with the top four at the end of the regular season making the finals. 
The top two teams face each other in a qualifier, with the winner going through to the final. 
The loser of the qualifier then takes on the winner of an eliminator between third and fourth. The winner of that match goes through to the final, which will take place on May 22 in Hyderabad.
